abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Privatization Support
            Project for Nigeria were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            effective inter-agency coordination and management of the
            different institutional agendas and interests across the
            infrastructure sectors are important for the smooth
            implementation of a project. This was seen to be
            particularly relevant for the successful realization of the
            Power, Gas-to-Power and to a lesser extent transport sector
            objectives. It is important to build institutional capacity
            in project management, financial management, and procurement
            at the beginning of the project. In particular, emphasis
            should be placed on having adequate procurement capacity in
            place before project effectiveness. Thus after conducting
            procurement capacity assessment of the implementing
            agencies, issues identified should be adequately addressed
            before effectiveness. Such issue will usually include having
            adequate procurement capacity, preparation of draft
            documents. Communications Strategy: It is important to have
            an active and effective communications strategy that is both
            pro-active in reaching out to specific stakeholders (e.g.
            Assembly members, labor, and unions) and the broader public
            and provide specific products and services to deal
            reactively with media commentary and other eventualities.
            Privatization is a process which depends on market
            conditions. More thorough upstream investment and risk
            allocation assessment would have better assisted the
            government in the preparation of transactions for market.
            While Bureau of Public Enterprises (BPE) capacity to
            undertake this due diligence augmented considerably over the
            life of the project, given the complexity of many of the
            sector issues this involved, even deeper institutional
            capacity and expertise was required. This will have included
            more robust IT systems to record and utilize the
            considerable diagnostic and technical data that has been
            accumulated on the different transactions across the sectors
            targeted. These lessons learned have been important to the
            design of the next generation Nigeria Electricity and Gas
            Improvement Project (NEGIP) and Public Private Partnership
            (PPP) projects.

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Privatization Support Project and
            Community Based Urban Development Project : amendments in
            the context of portfolio restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
This report authorizes amendments to two
            projects in response to requests from the Government of
            Nigeria for their restructuring. The first is the
            Privatization Support Project (PSP), Credit No. 3520. The
            Government has requested IDA to amend the Development Credit
            Agreement in order to reallocate the proceeds of the Credit.
            In addition, the Government has requested IDA to add a
            subcomponent to the PSP to provide technical assistance for
            a feasibility study of a gas pipeline and independent power
            production project.   The second project concerned is the
            Community Based Urban Development Project, Credit 3654. The
            Government has requested: (1) a reduction in counterpart
            fund contributions; (2) 100 percent financing o f goods,
            training, and operating costs; (3) modification of
            eligibility criteria for subprojects to finance more trunk
            infrastructure in addition to upgrading activities in new
            communities and additional works and goods procurement in
            communities where implementation is under way, especially
            with respect to sanitation; (4) focusing project activities
            from unallocated funds in those cities that are already
            actively participating in the project to ensure impact of
            investments and scaling-up o f upgrading; (5) broadening the
            scope of training and capacity building activities to
            include overseas trips that 8 contribute to relevant
            exposure; (6) performance bonus packages for performing
            staff; (7) redefining the Federal Project Coordination Unit
            (FPCU) to be under the Federal Ministry of Housing and Urban
            Development; and (8) allocation of funds to support the FPCU.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Privatization Support Project 1)
            supports transparent and effective implementation of
            Nigeria's privatization program; and 2) creates an
            enabling environment for private sector participation and
            competition in infrastructure services, notably in
            telecommunications and electric power. There are six project
            components. The first supports the government's program
            for sector reform and privatization in telecommunications
            and power infrastructure; finances preparation and execution
            of public enteprise divestiture transactions in the other
            sectors; finances competitively selected investment advisers
            and legal and technical advisers; and finances consultant
            studies. The second component finances and strengthens the
            government institutions responsible for undertaking the
            privatization program and sector reforms. The third
            component helps mount a major communications and public
            relations campaign at home and abroad to explain and
            publicize the reforms. The fourth component develops a
            national policy on telecommunications; reviews, develops,
            and implements new and comprehensive telecommunications
            legislation and regulations, among other telecommunications
            reforms. The fifth component develops a national power
            policy and a legal and regulatory framework, among other
            power sector reforms. The sixth component restructures the
            Lagos State Water Corporation (LWSC), and implements private
            sector participation and an emergency action plan to support
            LWSC during the transition.

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Privatization Technical
            Assistance Credit Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the environmental assessment
            (EA) for the Privatization Technical Assistance Credit
            Project, under which four key public enterprises will be
            privatized. As part of the divestiture processes,
            environmental issues are being addressed during project
            preparation, by including audits to analyze existing
            conditions at, and around specific sites, and facilities of
            the enterprises. The EA presents the results of the
            environmental pre-audits, ranking the enterprises with
            respect to requirements either for comprehensive or full
            audit, partial, or no audit. Environmental concerns include
            soil degradation, rapid deforestation, desertification, and
            droughts, in addition to constraints in generation,
            transmission and distribution of electricity to the national
            grid from hydropower dams, and gas fired thermal plants,
            with some immediate concerns, such as water, air, and noise
            pollution, poor sanitation, drainage, and solid waste
            management. Comprehensive, and partial audits address: 1)
            development of appropriate waste management practices
            regarding solid wastes, including oil spill contingency
            plans for the prevention, and control of spillage into
            downstream waters; 2) training assessment on environmental
            management plans, in accordance with the regulatory
            framework, and in liaison with the Ministry of the
            Environment; and, development of environmental mitigation,
            performance indicators, and monitoring; and, 3)
            identification of equipment decommissioning plans, in
            compliance with World Bank guidelines.
